Message.Title: What is Marissa Mayer's Top Secret Pet Project at Yahoo?
Message.Msg: SAI's source tells us friends of hers in Yahoo's product organization recently met with Mayer, and the CEO loved the product they showed her. Then came something very new to Yahoo. Mayer told the team she loves the new product so much that she wants it shipped by December 1 – months ahead of the schedule the team itself had put together. Mayer told the team they had one week to figure out if they could meet this deadline. If, at the end of that week, the team decided they would not be able to meet the December 1 deadline, Mayer said she would find a team that could.

Topic.Title: YAHOO is going to become an incubator + Wireless Asset Aggregator

Message.Msg: In putting together a deal, risk arbitrage wise, the lowest risk is the current $18B which will come from syndicated partner/investors. $7 Bil premium is basically already sitting in the bank and Loeb's acct.

Topic.Title: What is Marissa Mayer's Top Secret Pet Project at Yahoo?

Message.Msg: That story has been floating for weeks. Is it true and if so did they meet the one week deadline?

Topic.Title: Yahoo! Japan Sold Leaves Yahoo Vulnerable

Message.Msg: Yes, yahoo will become very inviting for either a buyout or to be taken over by private investor group. The first question for either option is what primium over current price would shareholders get? The next question us when? Before or after Alibaba IPO. The bad news about either option is that the buyer gains with time. The more time the more shares the company can buy back at lower prices. ( lowering there net cost and premium ). If insiders do have a "drag it out" plan it is cunning, and not exactly ethical, but is it legal (Barnes and Noble got away with it when they absorbed bnbn).

Topic.Title: message board issues

Message.Msg: Some of us CANNOT post unles we DELETE ALL of our temporary files and Deleete all of the files in our history each time we post! This because Yahoo is demanding that we be tracked by accepting Facebook, Google and ALL 19 of the Yahoo cookies that Yahoo wants you to ALLOW on your computer so they can SELL your profile to advertisers. If you have a problem posting it is more then likely you are blocking some tracking cookies or because You have a Do Not Track software enabled. Yahoo, Google and Facebook don't like that Do Not Track software !!!

Message.Title: US credit rating downgraded again - thanks Obama
Message.Msg: CNBC Sept 14 2012 - US credit rating cut by Egan-Jones again. Obama administration "quantitative easing" (pumping or overprinting money) is blamed for the credit downgrade to AA- from AA. S&P also rates US credit at AA-, and Moodys Investor Service also downgraded US credit last year and will do so again if the Democrat majority Senate does not pass a budget. (The republican House has passed several budgets only to be blocked by the Democrat Senate) The US has long enjoyed a AAA credit rating until two years after Obama was in the White House.

Topic.Title: Buy out

Message.Msg: If Yahoo knew how to "reinvest and recreate themselves as a creative and $ producing company", they would have done it THREE (or is it FOUR) CEOs ago. But they don't have a clue. Nor does the new high resume board. They don't know how to monitize their existing users. If they bought something, they couldn't run it anyway. This company is doing what it needs to do - liquidate.

Message.Title: The reason Yahoo can not go up is this...
Message.Msg: Too many selling. If you monitor the major shareholders for the past two years like I did, you would know, other than third point - the new largest shareholder, most of the major shareholders have been selling hard on Yahoo for the past two years or maybe longer but I didn't monitor Yahoo for that long. I was wondering if the cost of their shares were very low since Yahoo had been splitting its shares in the past a few times but I couldn't find out how low their cost was. Maybe $5, $10? I don't know. These major shareholders are still holding more than 70% of Yahoo shares and I have noticed that no matter what good news came out, they have never stopped selling and it looks like they are going to sell all of their shares without hesitation. I want to find out why. Because they had lost confidence and patience on Yahoo and wasted too much time on Yahoo and they decided to move on? I don't know. What I know is, most of the major shareholders had been selling covered puts for many years to drop their cost and it was very efficient since Yahoo had never really go up for the past four years. Would they stop selling Yahoo shares after Alibaba sale? I don't know either. Maybe the problem for Yahoo is, no growth, no matter how many cash Yahoo gets, it's revenue is dropping and it would eventually spend these cash either on IPhones or stock buy back. Since the core business is not doing so well and is still going down, Yahoo stock would never go up for another three years unless if there is a buyout which is not likely coming after Alibaba sale. So maybe that's why they will keep selling until they don't have any(they still have 70% left). All these sold shares would go to Yahoo itself since no other institutions are buying other than third point and I don't think third point could have bought all of their shares. So if you can wait, wait for Yahoo to buy back shares in the next three years gradually with the cash it got from Alibaba while the large institutions are selling their 70% shares. Maybe Yahoo's share will remain between $12 - $18 for the next three or five years until it got bought out or die. I had lost two years and didn't earn anything on Yahoo so I had to decide now if I want to wait another three years for a potential 20% gain or move on now for a faster return.

Mayer may well feel there is plenty yet to do in reducing payroll, developing new products etc. without going outside to spend a pile of cash. She is still working with the BOD on filling other top management posts. I, for one, see no reason to start carping about the use of the 85% especially when we do not even know the details. JMHO

Topic.Title: YAHOO is going to become an incubator + Wireless Asset Aggregator

Message.Msg: To answer your question about timing, none of our opinion matters, it is Loeb's view and his syndication to capitalize on Yahoo cash bank and low stock valuation. BUT judging by his action thus far, he is loading up fast and furious in just few months while the stock is basically trading under $16. I believe Loeb has been buying close to 80M shares. And Yahoo has been buying 40M shares. So far, over 12% of the float has been taken off the market. I am guessing Loeb is probably putting together the $18 Billion as we type. The partners or financier can see he has a PLAN and putting the $$ behind it to take it private. Marissa already made the CATTLE CALL to start-ups that she will be buying like an incubator + venture capitalist (competing against other venture capitalists). Her focus will be wireless assets since everyone will be spending more screen time on smart phones + I phones, hence her giving away them to all Yahoo employees as a test operation for all new wireless technology assets acquired.

Topic.Title: Very LOW HANGING FRUIT

Message.Msg: Unfortunately, people have been talking about offers for years! It is going to take a corporate buyer with a lot of in house talent to take over and run Yahoo (or to figure out how to cut it up and sell the parts). I do not know if Yang really has that ability. I'm guessing that Loeb and Co. is a seller. He is more likely to take his profit and run than go in deeper. Prior to Loeb, I would have said that any successful offer had to be UNFRIENDLY. Now, with Loeb controling the Board, it is possible that the directors would vote to accept something in the low $20's. The offer would have to come BEFORE they spend of distribute their new cash. We can always hope.

Message.Title: $3 special dividend - does anyone know this?
Message.Msg: I have not seen anywhere the estimated per YHOO share payout in the special dividend, have you? So I did the math using sources noted: - Amount to be paid out = $3.65B – source: WSJ article - Number of YHOO shares = 1.18B – source: Yahoo finance page for YHOO - Dividing amount to be paid by number of shares = $3.09 = payout per YHOO share Question: Do you think $3.09 per share is already baked into the current price? – or can we expect the price to rise as the market does the math?

Topic.Title: AOL, Special $5.15 CASH Dividend, Aug. 12

Message.Msg: At the April special dividend of $5.15, the stock was just above $18/share= 28%+ dividend. The stock proceed to pop 50%+. Ensuing months, the stock kept on rally another 50% after consolidation for 4 weeks. I don't follow AOL, but they must announced bunch of new initiatives on top of paying the $5.15 dividend. IF Yahoo pays $3. dividend and Marissa announced bunch of action plans, it would probably rally 33% (proportionally to AOL 28% dividend ) to $21+ change. BUT if Loeb does a take-private offer of 40% premium, you would get $22+change, which is a very good deal for Loeb and a likely event in the next few weeks for shareholders' sake. Some other posters suggested buyback is a better deal for shareholders, I AM NOT SURE- look at buying back 40M shares recently has done NOTHING for the stock price. IMHO FWIW

Topic.Title: AOL, Special $5.15 CASH Dividend, Aug. 12

Message.Msg: 27 Aug 2012 – AOL Inc. announced a $600 million accelerated stock buyback agreement and a special cash dividend of $5.15 a share payable on December 14, 2012 to shareholders of record at the close of business on December 5, 2012. The share price rose 94 cent the day of the announcement. Closed Aug 24 at $32.92 and Aug 27 at $33.86. AOL is now at $34.64.

Message.Msg: There's only one reason we invest in any stock, and it's to eventually make a profit. Unfortunately, there are too many people who fall in love with a company name or person (Marissa), and just want to be a bank, lending the company their money without any care about the amount or timing of the return. They can't even see the CEO or the Board laughing at them all the way to the bank. Look at all the CEO and Board failures, everyone of them walked away with millions. Marissa Mayer hasn't accomplished anything yet, but did you see her say her rewards would come after she delivered? Of course not, a fortune in bonuses an options paid up front, before the fact.

Topic.Title: Buybacks are Worthless

Message.Msg: I happen to agree with you once. The Core is where all the ills are, need to fix it, make it a lean and mean money generating machine again, investors will come. Personally I believe when MM was hired, she must have been given and agreed to be measured on some time based performance metrics as mandate, with stock performance being the primary measurement. With Dan Loeb on BOD, there has to be some firm expectation in share price appreciation by BOD (within a reasonable time window, say 12 months or 24 months, to make his investment worthwhile). Certainly hope MM can turn this thing around, but if she can't, BOD probably should have no hesitation to consider all other options to maximize investor value including aggressive cost cutting, sell non-performing/under-performing assets, etc.

Topic.Title: Buybacks are Worthless

Message.Msg: Yahoo needs to make the buyback and layoff at least 10,000 people. The former will get the eps up 50% moving the stock up. The latter will get the company in fighting shape. Forget the acquisition stuff and get the company monetizing it's assets.

Topic.Title: What is Marissa Mayer's Top Secret Pet Project at Yahoo?

Message.Msg: Well with all the disappointment surrounding YHOO, I think we ought to be a bit cautious. I haven't seen one iota of evidence so far that would tell me Marissa is a good CEO I still think we let go of "the Man" Levinsohn.

Topic.Title: Buybacks are Worthless

Message.Msg: If you believe the stock is under valued and Yahoo core will keep churning out earnings for a long time, I happen to think so, then stock buyback is the best way to return it back to investors, let's just hope it stays in the current range during the buybacks. Remember, with 20% less shares, your shares will be worth that much more (roughly). Coupled with what you said, cost cutting, monetizing, operational focus, etc, the share price will go up, just common sense.

Message.Title: Make no mistake, Yahoo will be sold for upwards of $35 when Yahoo Japan is settled
Message.Msg: Within 30 days of that.

Topic.Title: something? out there is suppressing the price of this stock!

Message.Msg: yes, you are correct. the market is valuing the core at zero. do a google search on "the value of yahoo core business"... it's all there. even the savior Loeb says so. Activist hedge funder Dan Loeb created this chart which shows the diminishing value of Yahoo's core business over the last seven years. He says the core businesses value has gone from $30 billion in 2008 based on the Microsoft buyout offer to $2 billion in the last six and half years. Loeb arrived at the value for Yahoo's core business by backing out the value of its cash, its stake in Alibaba (after taxes), and Yahoo Japan (after taxes). Importantly, this isn't necessarily a reflection of the true value of the business, just what the market thinks, says Loeb.
